fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a piecewise differentiable closed curve \gamma not passing through a, the complex line integral \int _\gamma \frac {1}{z - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} is always a multiple of 2 \pi i.

Intuitively, 1/(z-a) is the derivative of the function \log (z - a). But formalizing this is difficult, since logarithms are not single-valued, so what happens near the branch cuts is not clear. However, we can avoid this by considering the inverse function \exp instead.

Let the path be parametrized by the interval [0,1] for convenience. Consider the function g(t) = \int _0^t \frac {\gamma '(t)}{\gamma (t) - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. By the intuition above, we expect g(t) \xlongequal {?} \log (\gamma (t) - a) + C. So we instead consider h(t) = \exp (g(t))/(\gamma (t) - a) and prove it is a constant. This can be verified by differentiation, using the chain rule and the fundamental theorem of calculus.

Of course, \gamma is only piecewise differentiable. So h(t) is only constant on each piece. But in addition, h(t) is continuous on the entire curve, so it must be globally constant. Moreover, since \gamma is a loop, we have \gamma (0) = \gamma (1), and since h(0) = h(1), we can deduce 1 = \exp (g(0)) = \exp (g(1)), which means the integral g(1) is a multiple of 2 \pi i as desired.

From the definition of a holomorphic function, we can immediately start exploring some of its consequences. It turns out that complex differentiability is much stronger than real differentiability, and the following theorem gives a first glimpse.

Intuitively, for a function f to be complex differentiable, we need (f(z + \epsilon ) - f(z)) / \epsilon to converge to the same value for both real and imaginary \epsilon . The real and imaginary parts of this equality correspond to the two Cauchy–Riemann equations.
We can write these equations formally in a more suggestive way.

Considering \mathbb {C} as a two dimensional real space, the tangent space at a point (take zero as an example) is \mathbb {R}^2. It comes equipped with a complex structure J sending \partial _x \mapsto \partial _y and \partial _y \mapsto -\partial _x, acting as multiplication by i. A (real) smooth function \mathbb {C} \to \mathbb {C} then has a Jacobian at each point, which is a 2 \times 2 matrix M. The Cauchy–Riemann equations then imposes a condition on this matrix, which can be written as J M = M J.

It is sometimes convenient to complexify this vector space \mathbb {R}^2 \otimes \mathbb {C} = \mathbb {C}^2. This corresponds to formally allowing the x and y components to be complex-valued. This is because we often want to view a complex function as a scalar field on a two dimensional (real) manifold, but the scalar can be complex. So to do calculus with these scalars, naturally the associated tangent and cotangent spaces needs to be complexified. J now has two eigenvalues i and -i, corresponding to the holomorphic and antiholomorphic subspaces.

Of course this only happens in the tangent space, and the coordinate functions cannot be extended to complex domains. The Jacobian then extends to the complexified tangent space. This space has an alternative basis \partial _z = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x - i \partial _y) \quad \text {and}\quad \partial _{\bar {z}} = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x + i \partial _y). This has the dual basis on 1-forms, given by \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} + i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y} and \operatorname {d}\mathclose {\bar {z}} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} - i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y}. In this basis, the Cauchy–Riemann equation can be written as \partial _{\bar {z}} f = 0.
This gives a heuristic procedure for finding the harmonic conjugate of a function.

fr:title.text: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose u is the real part of some holomorphic function f. Then we have 2 u(x, y) = f(x + i y) + \overline {f(x + i y)}. If we could extend the coordinates x and y to complex numbers, then similar to what happens in the tangent space, we have a (z, \bar {z}) coordinate system with z = x + i y and \bar {z} = x - i y acting as independent variables in \mathbb {C}^2.

By the Cauchy–Riemann equations, f(x + i y) should only depend on z and \overline {f(x + i y)} should only depend on \bar {z}. So we can write the latter as another function g(\bar {z}). Since 2 u = f(z) + g(\bar {z}), we can look at the value at the point (z, \bar {z}) = (\alpha , 0) where \alpha \in \mathbb {C}, which corresponds to x = \alpha / 2 and y = - i \alpha / 2. Hence 2 u(\alpha / 2, - i \alpha / 2) = f(\alpha ) + g(0), which determines f up to some constant. This method requires an analytic expression of u(x, y), so it makes sense to plug in complex numbers into x and y.
The Cauchy–Riemann equations is very suggestive of the assumption in Green’s theorem in (real) multi-variable calculus. This prompts us to define notions of line integrals on the complex plane.

Given a complex function f and a piecewise differentiable curve \gamma : [a, b] \to \mathbb {C}, we can define a few different kinds of line integrals along \gamma . The first is the naive line integral, given by directly integrating \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. But this depends on the parametrization of the curve.

We can also define the complex line integral, which is independent of parametrization: \int _\gamma f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \gamma '(t) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. Following the convention of complexifying the (co)tangent space, we can write \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} + i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y}. This leads to the evident definition of integrating against \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x}, given by \int _\gamma f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \operatorname {Re}\gamma '(t) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. And \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y} is defined similarly.

Finally, there is also the arc length integral, which is given by \int _\gamma f(z) \left |\operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}\right | = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \left |\gamma '(t)\right | \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. In particular, integrating the constant function 1 gives the length of the curve.

fr:title.text: Integral of holomorphic function does not depend on path

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integral of holomorphic function does not depend on path

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a holomorphic function f on an open set U, the complex line integral of f along two homotopic paths are equal. This is a direct consequence of the Cauchy–Riemann equations and Green’s theorem. However, we need to be careful with the hypotheses when we have low differentiability.

We can write down the idea more succinctly using the notation of \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} and \operatorname {d}\mathclose {\bar {z}}. We are integrating along f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}, but this is an closed differential, since \operatorname {d} (f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}) = - \partial _{\bar {z}} f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} \wedge \operatorname {d}\mathclose {\bar {z}} = 0. This shows the power of complexifying the tangent space.

This applies when f is complex differentiable at every point, since complex differentiability implies (real) Fréchet differentiability (i.e. f can be approximated by a linear map at each point), which suffices for Green’s theorem to apply. It also suffices that f is the derivative of another holomorphic function, and it is Riemann integrable. In this case we can simply apply the fundamental theorem of calculus.

In fact, is still applicable when the function f is holomorphic except at isolated points z_i, but f(z) is o(|z - z_i|^{-1}). This can be seen by making the curve loop around a small disk of radius r around these bad points. The loop integral goes to zero as O(r) o(r^{-1}) = o(1), and so does not affect the result. This is important because there is a function in the definition of complex differentiability, namely g(z) = \frac {f(z) - f(a)}{z - a}. And so the integral of g(z) along a circle around a must be zero. Now we can separate out the second term f(a) \cdot \int _\gamma 1/(z - a) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}. This can be directly computed to be 2 \pi i f(a). This proves the following formula.

Given a holomorphic function f, and a point a such that a disk containing a lies within the domain of f, we have f(a) = \frac {1}{2 \pi i} \int _{\gamma } \frac {f(z)}{z - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}, where \gamma is the boundary of the disk.
Separating the two terms in the integral, we are left to prove \int _\gamma \frac {\operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}}{z - a} = 2 \pi i. This can be done by looking up integral tables.
The integral of 1/(z-a) can in fact be computed more generally. This also means we can use more general closed curves in , which will be useful in calculations.
